headline.main-hed: Detroit Creates 'Hybrid' Pension System to Trim Costs

alt-summary-body.p: Detroit said it would create a "hybrid" pension system that seeks to reduce its estimated $3.5 billion funding shortfall.

headline.main-hed: Detroit creates 'hybrid' pension system to trim costs
Detroit Creates 'Hybrid' Pension System to Trim Costs

summary-body.p: Detroit said it would create a "hybrid" pension system that seeks to reduce its estimated $3.5 billion funding shortfall.

headline.main-hed: Detroit Creates 'Hybrid' Pension System to Trim Costs
headline.deck: City Expects to Save $30 Million a Year; Plan Starts in July

article-body.p: DETROIT—The struggling city government said Wednesday it would create a hybrid pension system that aims to reduce an estimated $3.5 billion funding shortfall by having workers pay into the plan while keeping in place defined benefits.
Detroit is expected to save at least $30 million a year with the switch, which was negotiated with city unions, said Bill Nowling, spokesman for Detroit Emergency Manager Kevyn Orr.

The plan, effective in July, follows those of several states that require current employees pitch in to address funding gaps. Major U.S. public pension systems in 2012 had about $1 trillion in liabilities compared with assets, according to a survey sponsored by the National Association of State Retirement Administrators and the National Council on Teacher Retirement.

Hybrid plans are promoted as a way for governments to trim guaranteed-retirement payments. The plans shift more responsibility for funding retirement benefits to employees, but differ from the 401(k)-style, defined-contribution plans common among private employers.
In Detroit, most city workers will contribute 4% of their pretax weekly salary, which the city will match. Current police and firefighters will contribute 6% and new employees even more.
Some employees could see their pension deductions offset by salary increases intended to return workers to 2010 pay levels during the next four years.
The changes come as Detroit faces a courtroom showdown with creditors this summer concerning its plan to exit bankruptcy.

As part of the city's bankruptcy with about $18 billion in long-term obligations, the city sent ballots to roughly 32,000 existing retirees offering them a stark choice: vote for a plan to reduce most pensions and eliminate a future cost-of-living increase, or reject the plan and risk additional cuts.
Those reductions would be in addition to the new contributions for active employees under the plan unveiled Wednesday.
Write to Matthew Dolan at matthew.dolan@wsj.com
